ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You will become an expert in sitting with a poem until it opens itself up to you.

The course helps me to learn how to read poems as discourses. The theoretical apparatus in the course is incredibly robust (100% graduate-level theory), and that is very helpful because you get to see the way those smartest human minds read poetry.
Awesome course with an interesting lens through which to read some of the greatest poets.
Much improved confidence in tackling challenging poetic texts, and just generally opening my eyes to the limits, or lack thereof, of poetry and its effects in the world

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: More structure is needed when it comes to the discussion posts, but overall, this course was very strong. Both instructors were truly dedicated and passionate which was very exciting to see. Wonderful conversations took place in and outside the classroom.
This course was absolutely awesome-- no notes.

Really fun discussions every class, felt engaging and relevant, like I was actually learning something. Wish we could've received more detailed feedback on our actual assignments and how to improve upon them though

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Yale needs more poetry classes. I've left the class not only knowing more about poems, but about myself, and nature, and history, and the world!

Would 100% recommend any course with both instructors. They are incredibly good at guiding conversations and putting forward relavant insightful observations as well as asking questions. Heidegger says in the beginning of "The Questioning Concerning Technology" that "Questioning builds a way. We would be advised, therefore, above all to pay heed to the way, and not to fix our attention on isolated sentences and topics. The way is a way of thinking. All ways of thinking, more or less perceptibly, lead through language in a manner that is extraordinary." I feel this accurately describes their philosophy of asking questions (in seminars).
Yes!  An awesome poetry seminar led by some really smart and generous professors.  The vibe in the class was amazing.
Yes absolutely, regardless of prior poetry experience
